summary: About 60% of seaborne trade involves standardized shipping containers. Upon arriving at port, containers are placed on an "intermodal chassis"—a wheeled base frame for transporting shipping containers. In the U.S., several business models exist for providing chassis, and each model has benefits and drawbacks. For example, one business model groups chassis from multiple companies into a single pool, which can be used by any carrier...
title: Commercial Shipping: Information on How Intermodal Chassis Are Made Available and the Federal Government's Oversight Role
